subtitle: New Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove
Hello, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I’d like to talk about self-responsibility.
You may recall in the second segment of this “In Presence” series –
and, I hope that all of you who are watching this segment have watched at least the first three
by now – in the 2nd segment, I talked about unconditional self-love.
I described it, as I recall, in terms of the work I did many years ago as a trainer with Omega Seminars
developed by John Boyle a long time ago. The important emphasis on unconditional self-love.
As I recall, I also emphasised that love for oneself, unconditionally,
also implies a warm positive feeling akin to love for all other people at all times.
But there are a few more corollaries of self-love that I’d like to talk about now.
One of those is self-responsibility
So, if you’re working with affirmations -
one way to work with affirmations, of course, is to create a very positive feeling about them.
To have a positive visual image that you use with it.
Sometimes music helps and we’ve talked about the importance of self-suggestion
And, I’ve given you a self-hypnosis, or what I call guided meditation tape to go along with it.
Well, in the Omega Seminar, we worked with affirmations this way.
We had an affirmation that went: “I really enjoy the way I love myself unconditionally.
No matter what I do or say, or think or feel
or what other people do or say, or think or feel with regard to me, I love myself unconditionally.
And then I really love the way that I have warm positive feelings for all other people at all times.”
And then, and this has to do with self-responsibility:
“I really enjoy the way that I take responsibility for all of my actions at all times. I am completely responsible for the actions that I choose.”
This means no passing the buck now, no blaming other people.
I can only suggest that there may be a few limits on that.
And, of course, that has to do with the law and criminal activity.
I might choose, if I take that affirmation seriously all the way, to engage in criminal activity.
And yes, some people do, and do so for good reasons.
For example, people who engage in social protests,
and who are involved in sit-ins, and other kinds of social actions of that sort.
Henry David Thoreau wrote a wonderful essay on Civil Disobedience. There is a time and place for that.
But it means, not passing the buck.
And it means, and here’s the key:
There’s another corollary: “I really enjoy the way I take total responsibility
for all of my actions at all times.
And, I allow other people the same right.
I always allow other people the same right.
I never try to control
another person’s sense of self responsibility for their actions.”
And that’s one important way, incidentally, that I’m no guru.
Well, maybe, I am in the sense of this: guru - ‘gee’ ‘you’ ‘are’ ‘you’.
That’s what guru means to me. You are you. You have the right to be responsible for all of your actions at all times.
Not my responsibility.
Of course
we have the saying in the Bible: “Am I my brother’s keeper?’
Yes, you do have a right to speak out. You have a right to let your feelings [be] known.
If you see that somebody is engaging in harmful behaviour you have every right to offer that person constructive criticism.
constructive criticism
Not the kind of criticism that belittles them as a human being for who they are in their depths.
That’s very important, incidentally, in terms of the way you treat your children.
You certainly have every right to show people how they can improve their behaviour.
But that means
never trying to dominate other people,
to bend them to your will
And, especially in social circumstances
For example, I consider myself a feminist and I’m proud of it. I’ve mentioned this before in some segments
and I’ve gotten a little blow back from some people, like “What do you want? All men to become effeminate?
Or, what about the natural hormones that we have?
Males are intended to dominate.
Look at our primate ancestors, the gorillas and chimpanzees,
and many other species of animals where you have a male,
alpha male who dominates a family of animals.”
Well, I don’t subscribe to that model.
In fact, I think it’s kind of, to be honest, kind of cowardly to say,
“Well, we have to behave like chimpanzees or gorillas.”
The truth is this, with regard to feminism, and it is that
humans were not always patriarchal
The earliest history of humanity,
according to archaeologists
is that pretty much universally around the planet
–and I’m sure there’s some exceptions – but they worshipped the great Mother Goddess, the Fertility Goddess.
You can find images of this goddess throughout the world.
From all of the evidence – grave sites, burials, architectural structures, and so on –
it appears as if men and women were equal in these societies
We see it even, for example, in cultures like Ancient Egypt.
So, patriarchy came later. There’s a history of patriarchy.
It goes back to ancient Mesopotamia
and the Code of Hammurabi and the Sumerians.
But prior to that,
patriarchy was really not known amongst civilized cultures.
In fact, I did an interview with a historian on that very subject, Gerda Lerner.
And, if it’s possible for me to locate that video, I’m going to link to it right now so that you know.
But, even with regard to our primate ancestors
Yes, gorillas and chimpanzees do have this alpha male component but other primates don’t.
For example, bonobos, who are,
sometimes called miniature chimpanzees,
they are primates.
And actually, they don’t have a male dominated society at all
In fact, if anything, it’s the other way around.
You’ll find many native cultures – aboriginal cultures – on this planet, of humans who are not male dominated.
In fact, quite a few are female dominated.
But what I represent and what I stand for: self-responsibility, as I see it here,
is being responsible for myself, not trying to dominate other people.
That means, recognising that every other law abiding adult human being
has absolutely the same equal rights that I have. And I’m willing to stand up for that.
I believe that there is nothing effeminate, whatsoever, in standing up for the equal rights of all adults.
In fact, I would say that it's very important. I would say, furthermore,
for those of you who are opening up to your own psychic abilities:
these ethical guidelines are very important to live by.
So in conclusion
let me ask you to consider in your life:
Are you taking responsibility 100% for all of your actions?
If not, why?
Are you endeavouring to dominate or control the actions of any other adult
around you, or any other group of adults around you?
If so, why?
Consider this you may have been brought up that way.
Certainly, many cultures exist where there are underclasses of people who are dominated by the over-class.
Or, people who feel they have no choice
but to behave in a particular manner
because they’re too old, or too weak, or the wrong sex, or the wrong sexual preference.
Or, they’re a parapsychologist.
I don’t know what. Because, there’s certainly groups of people who will endeavour to
restrict the activities of other groups of people, that go over and above anything having to do with the criminal law.
But, if you’re involved in that in one way or another, either as the dominator or the dominated,
not under your own free will:
Ask yourself,
“Does it have to be this way?” What if you were to change?
I’ll leave you with that thought.
Thank you for being with me.
